text: In the Meno, Anytus had parted from Socrates with the significant words:
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: 'That in any city, and particularly in the city of Athens, it is easier
title: Euthyphro

text: to do men harm than to do them good;' and Socrates was anticipating
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: awaiting his trial for impiety. But before the trial begins, Plato would

author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Euthyphro

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: discussion.

author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Euthyphro

author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

author: Plato

title: Euthyphro

author: Plato

title: Euthyphro

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

author: Plato

text: and what is impiety. What then is piety?
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: Euthyphro, who, in the abundance of his knowledge, is very willing to
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: undertake all the responsibility, replies: That piety is doing as I do,
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

author: Plato

text: as the gods do--as Zeus did to Cronos, and Cronos to Uranus.
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: Socrates has a dislike to these tales of mythology, and he fancies that
title: Euthyphro

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: 'Are they really true?' 'Yes, they are;' and Euthyphro will gladly tell
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: a more satisfactory answer to the question, 'What is piety?' 'Doing as
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: I do, charging a father with murder,' may be a single instance of piety,
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: but can hardly be regarded as a general definition.
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: Euthyphro replies, that 'Piety is what is dear to the gods, and impiety
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: is what is not dear to them.' But may there not be differences of
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: opinion, as among men, so also among the gods? Especially, about good
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: and evil, which have no fixed rule; and these are precisely the sort of
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: differences which give rise to quarrels. And therefore what may be dear
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: to one god may not be dear to another, and the same action may be both
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: pious and impious; e.g. your chastisement of your father, Euthyphro, may
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: at the hands of their sons).
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: Euthyphro answers that there is no difference of opinion, either among
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: gods or men, as to the propriety of punishing a murderer. Yes, rejoins
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: Socrates, when they know him to be a murderer; but you are assuming the
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: point at issue. If all the circumstances of the case are considered, are
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: you able to show that your father was guilty of murder, or that all the
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: Socrates proceeds to analyze the new form of the definition. He shows
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: and therefore that which is dear to the gods is dear to the gods because
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: But the pious or holy is loved by the gods because it is pious or holy,
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: which is equivalent to saying, that it is loved by them because it is
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: dear to them. Here then appears to be a contradiction,--Euthyphro has
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: 'attends' to the gods, as there is another part of justice which
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: 'attends' to men. But what is the meaning of 'attending' to the gods?
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: The word 'attending,' when applied to dogs, horses, and men, implies
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: that in some way they are made better. But how do pious or holy acts
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: acts, acts of service or ministration. Yes; but the ministrations of the
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: husbandman, the physician, and the builder have an end. To what end do
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: we serve the gods, and what do we help them to accomplish? Euthyphro
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

text: or dear to them; and this is the point which has been already disproved.
title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro

title: Euthyphro

title: Euthyphro

title: Euthyphro
author: Plato

title: Euthyphro
